Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2008 06:33AM 2z54 wrote: Hi! I actually had a SNB last Thursday (8/28) and saw the surgeon yesterday. I was relieved to learn that both sides were cancer-free, and I congratulated the surgeon that neither incision hurt.  She was a bit concerned about the "swelling", i.e. lumpiness around each node/underarm, and said it was fluid.   She volunteered to aspirate them, but I elected not to since the fluid will recede and it does not hurt.  Time will heal and I am so relieved not to have had pain, numbness, or cancer in nodes. Hope that helps those of you who are also a bit swollen.   If it doesn't hurt.... no need to worry! s Sue
Posts.Title: "Lumpy" SNB Incision Site Kleenex Springtime

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2009 02:39PM - edited Nov 6, 2009 02:40PM by 2z54 Luah, It sounds to me like you may have mild lymphadema.  I did after my sentinel node biopsies, on each side. But, it was the right side; my dominant side, that had residual lymphadema.  I had discomfort down my right arm and swelling in my right hand. The Lymphadema physical therapist helped a great deal with their special massage, and provided sleeves and gloves for me to use post-double masectomy, which came after chemotherapy.  It turns out that after the masectomies and the removal of my chemo port, all of the swelling in my right hand went away.  You may want to ask your doctor about a recommendation for therapists in your area who specifically treat Lymphadema.  Or, check out the Lymphadema thread on this board. "Binny" is our resident expert!  (Don't worry, lymphadema is not as terrifying as it sounds. Mine is all gone now, and yours will be too, soon!) Sue
Posts.Title: Oh the joys of SNB recovery - let me count the ways Luah 2z54

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2010 05:56PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 02:46AM by 2z54 I marvel at these women who have been successfully taking Lupron for years. I'm 56 now, but when I was about 35 I had to take Lupron after having one ovary removed because of severe endometriosis.  The ovary removal wasn't so bad, but the Lupron injections made me feel like I thought an 80 year old woman must've felt; every bone and muscle ached!  I was supposed to do Lupron for 6 months - it was still experimental and cost a fortune back then.  Anyway, I only tolerated about 3 or 4 months and gave up.  My periods came back and in my mid 40s I started an early menopause (only had 1 half functioning ovary by then, anyway), and it was much easier to get into "gradual" menopause than the Lupron injections.  Now that I'm TN, the estrogen removal isn't that much of a concern.    I guess we're all different, but I for one, would elect ovary removal over Lupron.  But, maybe they've made it more tolerable now, too.  Good luck! Sue

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2010 03:39PM 2z54 wrote: Now that I'm 2 years out from dx, I've switched to stevia instead of aspertame/equal, etc. and improved my overall diet by staying away from processed foods wherever I can. I always drank diet drinks and used sweet&low, equal, splenda, etc.  That didn't seem to work for me, so I'm not waiting to hear the final word on it.  Good luck to you! sue

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2010 08:25PM 2z54 wrote: Yes. Xanax helps with sleep.  Lunesta helps with sleep. Ambien helps with sleep. There are many drugs available that help with sleep, and if you are just starting on this journey, you should probably speak with your primary to find one that works for you. Waiting for results was for me, probably the worst part of my bc experience.  My drug of choice for the waiting was valium.  I used Lunesta occassionally when I needed extra help sleeping. Do yourself a favor and make that call!  Meanwhile, I'll be keeping my fingers crossed and saying a prayer or two for your B9 results!  Keep us posted!

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2010 11:10PM - edited Jun 3, 2010 11:13PM by 2z54 JudyAnn, Kona is right!  There's always tomorrow, and the chance to bring more health and happiness into your life.  I'm trying to do that now, too and it's not always easy. I'm 56, exactly - just turned it an hour ago!  No kids, kinda separated from a husband who's relatively detached from me anyway, parents gone, blah blah blah.  Sometimes I feel pretty lonely, and a bit scared.  But, those feelings fortunately, are fleeting, because I try not to dwell on them and remind myself to keep focusing on more positive things.   Since the New Year, I've been making small positive changes in my life to improve my health and keep this beast (bc) from coming back.  I've lost 25 lbs. and quit smoking (most of the time!  ...but, I don't beat myself about it when I fall of the smoking wagaon, otherwise, I'd just quit quitting, and I don't want to do that). Anyway, I guess I'm really trying to live one day at a time and it must be working because I'm calmer about things (For example, I haven't worked in 6 months but, I'm not yet freaking out. I know that the universe will eventually provide!) Years ago, after my father died, I went on an anti-depressant because I couldn't stop crying just a little everyday. I know it's supposed to take weeks for them to start working but I swear the very first day I took my first pill, I didn't cry.  I no longer use them, but... I think that it might help you to try them. I think I was on zoloft.  My onc tried to get me to go back on them with the bc diagnosis, and I did thru chemo. But, I'm off now and doing OK. Don't look at it as something you'd always need to take - just something that can help you through the rough spots.   And, keep reaching out to everyone on this board.  They're all wonderful!!!  Personally, there have been many days when reading Kona's posts have either brought a smile to my face, or literally kept me going.  She's one of the treasures here, who has a great knack for putting things in perspective, often in a very funny;/humorous way!   Anyway.... hang in there JudyAnn!  Things will get better!  I definitely think you should do your chemo.  It's not as bad as the tv and movies make it out to be. And, like Kona says... it gives you more hope of a healthier/happier tomorrow, when you'll no longer need to be focused entirely on getting well.   Please let us know how you're doing, and feel free to PM me if you'd like to talk.  Sue

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2009 10:45AM - edited Sep 15, 2009 10:47AM by 2z54 Hi Klawless9, You really do look 10!  How lucky for you!!  What I really want to tell you though, is that you'll read other women's posts about getting nauseous after surgery and of course during chemo, etc.  Well, I had a bilateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction - it took 11 hours, and I never got nauseous after surgery. (Constipated, yes!). And with chemo, they give you so much anti-nausea medication, that the only reason to get nauseous anymore is not taking it.   That's what happened to me on my last treatment. I didn't take my anti-nausea meds (because I figured I didn't really need it) and 2 or 3 days after the chemo, I threw up; the first time on my last treatment, merely because I didn't take the meds. So, don't worry about getting nauseous. I hate it too, and it didn't happen. We're all different. The most important thing you can do for yourself is keep a positive attitude and know that you can get through this. Yes, it's definitely something to get through. And there will be days you'll want nothing but your life back.  But, you'll get through it and you'll be fine.  And yes, you'll get your life back!  Best of luck to you.  We're all in this together... sue

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2009 11:55PM - edited Nov 6, 2009 11:56PM by 2z54 I second the motion about Dr. Deborah Camal.  She was the first doctor I saw after the mammogram/biopsy diagnosis. She spent over 2 hours with me (at end of day) discussing all of my options and next steps.  And guided me to a fantastic plastic surgeon, Dr. Negyn Griffith, who performed a bilat DIEP after Dr. Camal's double mast.  I think G-d sent me to Dr. Camal!  But actually, it was my sister in law, to whom I will be eternally grateful! Good luck on this journey!  You'll be  fine.... Sue
Posts.Title: Need Breast Surgeon in Central NJ Purpleladi angie27

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2009 06:21AM - edited Sep 28, 2009 06:26AM by 2z54 Chelee, I read your post with a big "me too" smile!  I never got nauseous either with Chemo, but I continued to take my anti-nausea pills right up until the last dose-dense taxol infusion.  With that infusion, I took the pills on the day of chemo, and then stopped.  On the fourth day after, I threw-up for the first time!  Didn't even feel nauseous... it just happened. But it wasn't that big a deal either. So, those pills worked even when we didn't think we needed them!  At least for me.... Be well everyone! sue
Posts.Title: Should I be Sick Pure Leah_S

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2010 04:21AM 2z54 wrote: Hi Clare! I don't know how to answer your question about affording to go ahead with the surgery yourself when you're 18. But, I tend to agree with you that you should certainly be vigilant about your breast lumps.  Have you spoken to the doctor who did the original biopsy? Does s/he think the biopsy is critical/necessary, or is s/he satisfied with watching it carefully via mammo and/or ultrasound?   I would certainly try to speak to the doctor yourself, until you feel more comfortable about the process; and how you can be certain that the new lumps are not bc, without biopsy.  If s/he feels that a biopsy is the best thing to do, perhaps s/he can convince your mother to go ahead with the procedure.  On a positive note, remember that a very small percentage (I can't remember the exact figure) are cancer. So don't be consumed with fear. But, don't wait until you're 18 to find out! Good luck, and please keep us posted! Sue

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2009 10:09PM 2z54 wrote: One more thing about eating.... I was starved when I woke up!  But I had immediate reconstruction and my 2 wonderful surgeons were concerned that they might have to go in and fix my left flap (I had a double DIEP).  So, for 3 days, I couldn't eat!  Just ice chips.  They need to keep your stomach empty, apparently, in case they have to operate to save the Flap. Fortunately, my body fixed itself and in the evening of the third day I had............ a chef salad!  It was delicious, and trust me... you'll need the salad and Senokot to go to the bathroom! Good luck everyone!  Sue

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2010 10:57PM 2z54 wrote: Hi Sincitydealer, I know from experience with my mom, who passed away last October at 89, that wearing those pads all day can cause UTIs, no matter how often they are changed. Perhaps it has to do with air circulation and the fact that the material the pads are made of are designed to keep moisture in.  I always had to encourage my mom to drink plenty of water too - which would also help prevent UTIs.  Every time I brought her to the ER for one thing or another, she was always dyhdrated. I may be over-generalizing, but I think the WWII generation grew up without drinking much water.   Hope you find a doctor who will get to the bottom of it, soon!  Sue

I will have bilateral mast. and reconstruction. Then, hopefully, I'll get my life back and all will be well.  But, I'm grateful that they were both found now so that I don't have to go through this again.  Good luck to you!  Hoping the other one's a cyst or b9, too. Posts.Title: They found another lump during MRI Lita wishiwere

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2009 08:40PM - edited Jan 1, 2009 08:41PM by 2z54 Hi Coleen and Diane, I'm by no means a lymphodema expert, but I have a very mild case of it on my right hand and it was accompanied by "cording".   Basically, my lymphadema started about 4 to 5 weeks after my SNB; only had 2 nodes removed on rt. side and 1 node on left. Got lymphedema mildly on right - not on left. Anyway, my PS sent me to a lymphadema specialist who is also a physical therapist so we've been working on a lot of muscle issues and stretching. The cording seemed to go away after about 2 - 3 weeks of stretching and massaging, but I still have a bit of lymphadema swelling on my hand. Sorry I don't have better answers, but others who know more about lymphedema will be around soon. I just wanted you to know that the cording may very well be a result of the SNB... but it goes away fairly quickly with a little attention.  Good luck! sue
Posts.Title: Eeek - a CORD! I'm freaking out... Kleenex knowledgeforpower

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2009 01:41AM 2z54 wrote: Hi Achen! I saw your post and since I had bilat with DIEP in Jan '09, I thought I might be able to help a little.  First off, if none of the surgical sites hurt at all, you're doing good!  Your pain meds are probably working fine too. But, your pain meds may be causing the heart burn. I have no idea about the aching lower back, other than those skimpy hospital mattresses?   I was in the hospital for 7 days, 4 of which were in intensive care.  I wasn't really walking around much for the first 4 days, since they were concerned that I might have to go back to the OR to repair the left side.  Anyway, it all worked out. But, I think you should ask your doctors or nurses when you should be walking, and how much.  As for the pain, keep hounding them about that too.   The swelling can last quite a while though.  I'm three months out and still have some swelling on my right side. I remember during the 4th week post op thinking that I was healing very slowly because I was still very swollen. It turns out I had mild truncal lymphadema. It's almost all gone now. Don't worry - it takes time, but eventually you'll feel very much like your old self again!  Good luck! Sue

And, althought the economy sucks, it will work out. I'll spare you all the gory details, but one thing I think I've learned from my experience with bc (at 55), is that life is too short to hate your job.  I, too, had a long commute and a boring job.  It just wasn't worth it.  We survived bc, we can survive a little unemployment!  Best of luck to you! Keep up the great 'tude! sue

Posts.Title: I LIVE ALONE - post bi lat mast help? wabiwoman Jeansbeans

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2010 09:12AM - edited Mar 3, 2010 09:14AM by 2z54 Hi 3k, Just a word of caution, and personal tale... When diagnosed in 7/08, I worked for one of the America's best employers, a high tech company that starts with "G".  (The company that hired me had been bought out by them).   Well, I worked through chemo but went on disability leave afterward for surgery.  When I returned from surgery I had the boss from hell. At the original company I had had an agreement to work from home 2 days a week.  It was a long commute, so because of my mild lymphadema, I requested an extra laptop to keep at home.  My boss rolled her eyes like that was a huge request, reserved primarily for executives. But, I got it.   Within 2 months I also started getting warning reviews.  In one review, it was mentioned that I was not "focused".  I sent HR an article about chemo brain that I found on this website, to help them understand other cancer patients that might be in their employ.  I finally responded to my last warning, which was actually a Performance Improvement Plan with a letter of discrimination to HR (I was 55 and a cancer survivor).  To make a long story short, I believe that my high tech company wasn't too interested in nurturing aged cancer survivors, and in fact, were on a mission to rid themselves of me.  I finally hired a lawyer who got me some severance, although I believe I could have eventually won a discrimination suit.  But, it would have taken years and I just wanted "out" of the daily micromanagement and harrassment. Long story short again; HR is not our friend.  They are paid to protect the company.  If I were you, I would stay under HRs radar. The company knows you have cancer; they will always know whether it's in your review or not.  Best to play it safe and be satisfied with whatever promotions come or do not come.  Bringing more attention to yourself only makes you vulnerable, and sometimes companies want to rid themselves of problem children.  Best of luck to you! Sue
Posts.Title: Review @ work - was this professional?Or called for? 3katz rayofsun

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2010 03:43PM - edited Feb 22, 2010 03:44PM by 2z54 Hi Dana, I was having a blm with immediate DIEP, and that was scheduled a month after my last chemo. So, I took that month between chemo and surgery off to try to get in shape, i.e. exercise, eat well, etc.  At the point I decided to take "pre-surgery" time off, we asked for a total of 3 months, and it was granted - and pretty standard.  (I should add that I had worked from home during chemo from Sept. thru Dec. 1)  My disability leave started Dec. 1 and I was supposed to be back at work on March 1, or so.  However, I didn't heal as quickly or as well as we hoped - probably because of the chemo first and my age (54), and we requested another 2 months at the end of Feb.  The extra 2 months were granted and I returned to work on May 3 or so.  I was lucky to have company-issued disability insurance.  Many years ago I had my own business and didn't have disability coverage. It really came in handy! Sue
Posts.Title: Taking plenty of time off dana14 2z54

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2010 09:11PM 2z54 wrote: Your disability leave is more than likely to be approved.  Your PS and Onc will need to submit the papers, in which they estimate how much time you'll need - which is usually standard, based on your treatment.  I went on leave for 5 months. Hope that helps! Sue

Posts.Title: in the years after TC treatment limegreen hrf

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2008 09:29PM 2z54 wrote: Hi WishIwere, I was just diagnosed on 7/23/08. Haven't started anything yet but it looks like a bilateral with chemo, rads, everything. Today I had my BRAC tests, because..... every woman on my father's side has died of breast cancer or had masectomy (2 aunts in early 70s and grandmother - not sure what age of masectomy).  The geneticist told me I have a 65% chance of having the mutation.  I'm almost positive I do, and because I already have one 3.5 cm trip neg. in left breast and a very small (7mm trip positive) in right breast... I'll do the masectomies.  The question now is what about the ovaries?  I'm 54 and already in menopause.  I'm not looking forward to estrogen therapy for the small lump, but I guess I'll do whatever they tell me to do.   If you can get the test... it sounds like a good idea.  For me, it will confirm the decision to have the bilateral, help me to decide about the ovaries, and give my niece more information than I ever had when I was growing up. Good luck! 2z
Posts.Title: BRCA2 positive and now what??? seoulite tweekerbeeker
